posts.name: Jugad S.
posts.cooked: We are attempting to utilize Megatag 2, yet when displaying the position on AdvantageScope, it seems to shift whenever we rotate. We are relying on the get robot orientation data from our Pigeon 2 system. Our code source is available here: https://github.com/jugads/1391_COMP/blob/HoustonCMP/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/CommandSwerveDrivetrain.java

A little more information wouldn’t have hurt, but here’s my take on it.  
First, if you try MT1 instead, things seem okay, but let me explain how I think it works:  
You update the gyro first, followed by the vision, and then set the robot’s orientation. From that perspective, when a tag is detected, the system gives priority to vision over gyro data because it relies on the latter as a ground truth. Of course, this is just a hypothesis and might not be accurate.

posts.name: Jugad S.
posts.cooked: What information would you like? I'm happy to provide updates. I made further changes recently. If you'd like, review them and share your thoughts. Throughout the season, we used MT1, which was sometimes slightly inconsistent but generally effective.

Did it work with the changes, or will you have to wait to test?

Scrolling through the commit (on my phone rn, so it’s a bit harder), is there a reason you changed to use the MT x and y, and then the gyro yaw? Probably not the ideal approach, as it relies on your gyro yaw being initialized exactly correctly—which it may not always be.

In terms of improving vision performance, what exactly wasn’t great? MT2 could be the solution, but it also might not change much.

After reviewing your code, here are the clarifications:

1. The `LimelightHelpers.setCameraPose_RobotSpace()` function isn't present in your robot program. Ensure the camera’s robot-space pose is configured in the Limelight web UI. Failing this, the system assumes the camera is centered, which could affect tag angle measurements and pose estimation accuracy.

2. The SwerveDrivePoseEstimator in CommandSwerveDrivetrain seems redundant. The pose estimator is already operational at a higher frequency, handling module positions and orientation internally. Use `getState().Pose` for yaw and incorporate MT2 estimates via `this.addVisionMeasurement()`.

3. Avoid adding pigeon yaw corrections through `addVisionMeasurement()`, as they're already integrated into the pose estimator. According to the Limelight documentation, set the MT2 yaw measurement standard deviation to a very high value when configuring the pipeline.

For further reference on MT2 usage, visit [GitHub example](https://github.com/CrossTheRoadElec/Phoenix6-Examples/blob/main/java/SwerveWithPathPlanner/src/main/java/frc/robot/Robot.java).

link_counts.title: Robot Localization with MegaTag2 | Limelight Documentation

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked: I don't think that's the problem. The pose estimation calculations happen separately from when the gyroscope sends its data. Also, during each testing cycle, the gyroscope shouldn't update by more than a few degrees, so it probably isn't causing significant issues. I believe the limelight's orientation was slightly off.

The robot turns 0.5 degrees during each cycle. The pose estimator updates the robot's pose based on this change. However, the limelight pose, derived from the pose estimator's previous rotation, results in a pose reflecting only the prior cycle's rotation. The system does not utilize standard deviations (stdevs) but likely employs default values that are relatively low. Consequently, the pose estimator replaces the 0.5-degree adjustment with the vision-based update, meaning the gyroscope's rotation hasn't affected the robot's actual pose. Over multiple cycles, this could lead to translational movement when the robot rotates in place.

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked: Limelight’s are almost always using an old gyro rotation value though. When you call the setRobotSpace function, all you’re doing is sending an array over networktables to the limelight. The limelight sends any calculated poses back to the robot over networktables as well. Since both actions have latency, and the limelight calculates poses asynchronously from the robot’s periodic loop, the point that you send your gyro angle to the limelight has a very low chance of having any bearing on the measurement you receive from it.

At first, I thought it might be due to the timestamp issue, but after double-checking the code, that wasn’t the case. It could potentially be a calibration issue. Have you calibrated your Limelight? Is the problem more severe when the tag is near the edges of the vision?

posts.name: Jugad S.
posts.cooked: It didn't work with the changes. Answering a few other questions, the LL pose is configured in the web UI. We plan to use the internal pose estimator. Later, I'll send a video to help everyone understand the issue.

posts.name: Jugad S.
posts.cooked: Ok, I copied pasted the CTRE sample code with some minor tweaks and shared it. I also attached a video for reference. Thank you all for your assistance!

posts.name: Jugad S.
posts.cooked: The green robot in the video is the LL Limelight used in the code and the blue one is 'mypose'.

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked: Where did you have the robot on the field in relation to which April tag when you were testing this?

posts.name: Jugad S.
posts.cooked: It was on the processor side of the blue side looking at tags 17 and 22 and rotating at the same time.

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked: Which pose(s) shown in the video were closest to the robot’s actual position?

posts.name: Jugad S.
posts.cooked: In the very first frame, the green pose is correct except for the rotation, whereas the blue one is suitable for rotation. No translation was performed; only rotation was executed.
Ensure you've accounted for all offsets in the Limelight web UI. Verify the correct yaw offset and address any negatives you may have overlooked.

The code in the drivetrain's periodic() method includes logging angles in degrees instead of radians. Specifically, there's a comment mentioning that the logging should use radians rather than degrees, suggesting the need to adjust how rotation values are recorded.

posts.name: Jugad S.
posts.cooked: Yeah, I’ve seen that before. It’s just been a habit because of the season. Thanks for letting me know about the field2d method.

accepted_answer.excerpt: If by configured you mean setting the pipeline orientation to “upside-down,” this will not change how the data is processed. To actually adjust the apriltag tracking, you need to set the LL Roll to 180 in the advanced menu. Try doing that if you’re still having issues.
